title.narrative: UNICEF catch-up and drop-out education programmes
UNICEF catch-up and drop-out education programmes

description.narrative: Out-of-school boys and girls who are ineligible for formal schooling have access to the Catch-Up programme and the Drop-Out programme. For students attending the Catch-Up programme, the aim is for them to integrate into the formal school system upon completion.

Krisen i Syrien har alltjämt sedan 2013 gått emot det sämre i både Syrien och grannländerna och i den situationen är barn och ungdomar på flykt den mest utsatta befolkningsgruppen. Enligt UNICEF’s beräkning befinner sig 81,000 syriska barnflyktingar i Jordanien ’out-of school’, d.v.s. utanför den formella skolgången.
Mot bakgrund av de kritiska behoven har Jordaniens Utbildningsministerium med stöd av UNICEF utvecklat ett ”Catch-up classes programme” och Sida har tagit del av ett programförslag med tillhörande dokumentation.
Programmet riktar sig till barn, både syriska flyktingbarn och andra barn av olika nationaliteter bosatta i Jordanien i åldern 8-12, som har varit utanför det formella skolsystemet i över tre år, och som därigenom ej längre är behöriga att påbörja formell utbildning. Insatsen är en central del av det bredare UNICEF-initiativet ”No Lost generation”, som startade 2013 - där utbildning och barns rätt till trygghet och skydd utgör den grunden för Syrienresponsen både i Syrien och i grannländerna.
Efter att barnen utexaminerats från "Catch-up programme", har de sedan möjlighet att återuppta sin formella skolgång, vilket även är ett centralt syfte. Programmet har som mål att ge 25,000 barn i åldrarna 8-12 förutsättningar att studera inom ”Catch-up classes” varje år, för att möjliggöra deras inträde/återinträde till formell skolgång.
Programmet stödjer genomförandet av Sveriges Regionala Strategi för Syrienkrisen 2016-2020 och specifikt Resultatområde 1: ”Stärkt resiliens i Syrien och grannländer med fokus på bättre försörjningsmöjligheter, ökad tillgång till samhällstjänster och minskat könsrelateratvåld”.
Programmets totala budget är 50 MUSD födelat på två år, och Sidas stöd ligger på 30 MSEK för två år, varav 20 MSEK planeras utbetalas 2016, och resterande 10 MSEK under 2017.

The ongoing crisis in Syria and the neighboring countries has forced children and young people to flee to find safer havens. According to UNICEF's estimate, 81,000 Syrian refugee children in Jordan are 'out of school' and do not attend any formal schooling.
In light of this critical need, the Jordanian Ministry of Education with the support of UNICEF, has developed a "Catch-up school programme".
The programme is designed for both Syrian refugee children and other children of different nationalities residing in Jordan aged 8-12 who have been outside the formal school system for over three years hence no longer qualified to attend any formal education. The initiative is central to the broader UNICEF initiative "No Lost Generation", which commenced in 2013 to ensure quality education and children's right to security and protection as part of the Syria response in both Syria and in neighboring countries.
Children who complete the Catch-up programme have the opportunity to resume their formal schooling, which is the ultimate programme objective. The programme aims to provide an opportunity for 25,000 children to study in the "Catch-up classes" annually, to enable their entry or re-entry to formal schooling.
The programme supports the implementation of Sweden's Regional Strategy for the Syria Crisis 2016-2020 and specifically the Result Area 1: "Strengthened resilience in Syria and neighboring countries with a focus on improved livelihoods, increased access to public services and reduced gender-based violence".
The total budget from all donors is $50 Million USD over two years while Sida's support is 30 MSEK over two years, of which 20 MSEK is planned for 2016 whereas the remaining 10 MSEK for 2017.

sector.narrative: Facilitation of orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobility

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The supported project contributed to granting quality educational services to children in Jordan including Syrian refugees. Specifically, This project contributed to mainly two results, the first is reaching out-of-school children aged between 8-12 years old ineligible for formal schooling with Catch-Up Classes and the second is reaching out-of-school children aged between 13-20 years old are reached with Drop-Out Classes. UNICEF has supported the Ministry of Education in expanding schools in refugee camps in 2016, bringing the total number of schools in camps to 45 schools across 17 complexes, providing Non- Formal Education (NFE) opportunities for 3,179 (47 per cent female) children. Support from Sida has contributed to the expansion of NFE Catch-Up classes in refugee camps and host communities. In 2016, 1,615 children (764 female, 851 male) enrolled in the programme, in 67 centres. A total of 555 were referred and integrated into formal schooling after having made progress in the Catch-Up programme. In 2017 of the programme, 1,564 children (740 female, 824 male) were enrolled into the programme. In total 3,179 students were reached through Catch-Up
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
